attributes.title: Physical Stock Take
attributes.description:
a.)   Raw materials and finished good.

·       A physical stock count of raw materials and finished products was conducted on March 10 2025, at the D2 and D3 branches. The purpose was to verify the accuracy of inventory records in the SAP system by comparing them to actual stock levels and to assess the effectiveness of existing stock control measures.

·       The stock verification process revealed discrepancies between recorded and actual inventory levels, as follows:

Overages:

Ø  Bread stock: +6.25 pieces,

Ø  Polybags: +2,882 pieces,

Ø  Wheat bran: +18.93 kg,

Ø  Brown flour: +36.40 kg,

Ø  Brown bread ingredients (7 kg bags): +0.73 bags.

Shortages:

Ø  Yeast: -0.42 sachets,

Ø  Vegetable oil (Utto): -5.02 kg,

Ø  White flour: -57.63 kg,

Ø  White ingredients (9 kg bags): -1.15 bags.

·       Below is the summary of the audit finding:

Table 1: Stock take summary.

b.)   Crates movement.

·       A review of crate movements at the branch was conducted on February 13 2025 to assess the effectiveness of crate control measures.

·       The review confirmed that there was no variance between the SAP-recorded crate balance and the physically accounted-for crates. However, 295 crates belonging to the Dandora 1 branch were present at the branch. The opening balance for the branch stood at 1,065 crates.

Implication:

·       The presence of both shortages and overages suggests weaknesses in inventory management.

·       Inventory discrepancies especially shortages may indicate potential pilferage, misappropriation or unauthorized stock movement within the branches

Significant opening balances in crates is an indication that the crates controls are weak which poses a high risk of loss.
attributes.recommendation: The branch management should conduct a root cause analysis for significant stock discrepancies and implement corrective measures to prevent recurrence.
attributes.remediation_plan:
• Conduct an immediate reconciliation of physical stock against system records.

  • Adjust stock records to reflect actual inventory by the invoicing department

  • Establish a stock variance threshold policy to define acceptable limits

attributes.title: Bread Weight Check
attributes.description:
·       A weight verification exercise was conducted on packed bread ready for dispatch to ensure compliance with the standard weight categories set by KEBS: 400g, 600g, 800g and 1.5kg.

·       The assessment revealed discrepancies in bread weights with both underweight and overweight occurrences across different varieties:

Ø  600g Ct-5% underweight, 20% overweight

Ø  600g Bt-3% underweight,11% overweight

Ø  800g Naivas-4% underweight,33 % overweight

Ø  800g Bw-8% underweight, 34% overweight

Ø  600g Bw- 20% overweight,

Ø  600g BBW-2% underweight,82% overweight,

Ø  1.5Kg Ct/Bt-2% underweight & 9% overweight.

·       Below is the summary of the findings:

Table 2: Bread weights.

Implication:

·       The weight variations indicate possible lapses in process control such as inconsistent dough scaling or inadequate cooling time management.

·       Overweight bread results in excessive raw material usage increasing therefore production costs and reducing profit margins.

Non-compliance with weight standards may attract regulatory fines and may impact the firm’s reputation negatively.
attributes.effect:
·       The weight variations indicate possible lapses in process control such as inconsistent dough scaling or inadequate cooling time management.

·       Overweight bread results in excessive raw material usage increasing therefore production costs and reducing profit margins.

Non-compliance with weight standards may attract regulatory fines and may impact the firm’s reputation negatively
attributes.remediation_plan:
• Root Cause Identification of  weight loss such as machines breakdowns, packers pace and addressing Key Issues.

  • Monitoring strict adherence to production guidelines.

  • Regular checks and reviews on bread packed and bread before being distributed to market.

attributes.title: Bread damages Percentage Analysis
attributes.description:
·       A thorough evaluation of bread damage covering both production losses and market deformities was conducted from February 7 2025, to March 10 2025, to assess the branch’s adherence to quality standards.

·       It was noted that:

Ø  Production-related damages accounted for 0.33% of total output surpassing the acceptable limit of 0.2%.

Ø  Market (supermarket) damages were recorded at 1.55% of total sales exceeding the set threshold of 1.0%.

Table 3: Production Damages.

NB: The production damages analysis above excludes the oven damages of 366 loaves.

Table 4: Market Damages.

Implication:

Consistently exceeding the set limits for damages indicates non-compliance with internal performance benchmarks necessitating corrective measures moving forward.
